title: Drue Heinz’s Manhattan Townhouse Sells for $13 Million
text:
A Manhattan townhouse that was owned by the estate of the late philanthropist Drue Heinz, who was married to ketchup and canned-bean fortune heir Henry John "Jack" Heinz II, has changed hands for $13 million.



The buyers are Andrew Bolton and his partner Thom Browne, according to the deed filed with the city registry Thursday.



Mr. Bolton, who is in his early 50s, is the curator in charge of the Costume Institute of The Metropolitan Museum of Arts in New York. He is behind galas such as “Savage Beauty” and “China: Through the Looking Glass.” Mr. Browne, also in early 50s, is a fashion designer who worked at Giorgio Armani, Club Monaco and Ralph Lauren before starting his namesake label.



Both of them couldn’t be immediately reached for comment.

The brick Georgian townhouse came onto the market for $21 million in September 2018, The Wall Street Journal reported. The price was dropped to $18.5 million in January.



“Even in a challenging market, a contract was signed within four months but took awhile to close,” said listing agent Mary C. Kent of Sotheby’s International Realty.



Sitting on the northeast corner of East 57th Street and Sutton Place, the townhouse is 20 feet wide and more than 70 feet long, featuring a distinctive blue door. It includes 7,000 square feet of interior living space with views of the garden and the East River, according to the listing.

The townhouse was designed in 1920 by Mott Schmidt for Anne Vanderbilt, wife of railroad heir William Vanderbilt. The property was later owned by Charles Merrill, the co-founder of Merrill Lynch.



Heinz bought the townhouse in the mid-’70s, according to The Wall Street Journal. She died in March 2018 at age 103. The estate would donate part of the proceeds of the sale of the townhouse to charities Heinz supported.



Heinz was well-known for her literary pursuits and art collection. She was the publisher of the Paris Review from 1993 to 2008. A painting from her extensive collection of impressionist and modern works, “Meules” by Claude Monet, sold for $110.7 million at Sotheby’s in May.
